data.title: Command Education
data.meta_description: Duke University, located in Durham, North Carolina, is a prestigious private research university renowned for both its academic programs and vibrant campus life. Founded in 1838 as Trinity College before becoming Duke University in 1924, Duke is known for its rigorous academics, Gothic architecture, and diehard basketball fanbase.
data.text:
Duke University, located in Durham, North Carolina, is a prestigious private research university renowned for both its academic programs and vibrant campus life. Founded in 1838 as Trinity College before becoming Duke University in 1924, Duke is known for its rigorous academics, Gothic architecture, and diehard basketball fanbase.

Students who thrive at Duke are those who are intellectually curious, driven, and eager to engage in both academic and extracurricular activities. With a student-to-faculty ratio of 8:1, Duke offers a tight-knit and supportive learning experience, encouraging close interaction between students and professors. The university’s commitment to global education is evident through its numerous study abroad programs and research opportunities worldwide. Additionally, Duke’s vibrant campus life, characterized by a plethora of student organizations, sports teams, and cultural events, ensures that students have a well-rounded and enriching college experience. Whether you’re passionate about academics, athletics, or community service, Duke University can provide the resources and support necessary to help you excel and make a meaningful impact.

How difficult is it to get into Duke?

Admissions at Duke are highly selective—for the Class of 2027, 6.3% of the nearly 50,000 applicants were accepted. The Early Decision acceptance rate was higher than the Regular Decision acceptance rate, at 16.5% and 5.2%, respectively. The middle 50% of SAT scores ranged from 1520-1570, while the middle 50% of ACT scores ranged from 34-35.

What is the campus like at Duke?

Duke is located in Durham, North Carolina, a small city home to big companies like IBM, Credit Suisse, and Biogen. Over 150 years old, Durham has a long history and a flourishing arts and food scene. The city will provide many welcome opportunities for adventure when you’re in need of a study break or a weekend night out.

Duke comprises two campuses located in close proximity to one another in Durham. East Campus features Georgian-style buildings, spacious quads, and several residence halls. It is also home to the iconic East Campus Union, where students gather for dining, studying, and socializing. Known for its stunning Gothic architecture, West Campus is where most of Duke’s academic and administrative buildings are located, including the iconic Duke Chapel. This area also houses many upperclassmen residences, libraries, research centers, and the Duke University Hospital. The West Campus is the heart of academic life, with lecture halls, laboratories, and faculty offices.

Freshmen typically live on East Campus; however, since you’ll be required to live on campus for three years, you’ll likely live on West or Central Campus as an upperclassman. Duke has 600+ student organizations, including the Duke Disability Alliance, the Black Student Alliance, and the International Association. With hundreds of clubs to choose from, you’ll be sure to find your niche, and maybe explore something you haven’t before.

Duke’s campus is designed to cater to all aspects of student life. There are numerous dining options, including the Marketplace on East Campus and the Brodhead Center on West Campus. Student unions, such as the Bryan Center, host a variety of events, activities, and student organizations.

The university’s libraries, such as the Perkins Library and the Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, provide extensive resources and study spaces. Duke’s commitment to research is evident in its numerous specialized research centers and laboratories across disciplines.

The Sarah P. Duke Gardens, located on West Campus, are a highlight of the university, offering 55 acres of beautifully landscaped gardens. Students and visitors alike enjoy the serene environment for relaxation, study, and outdoor activities.

What is Duke known for?

Duke is known for its competitive basketball team and its dedicated Blue Devil fanbase, known as “Cameron Crazies.” Students are even known to camp outside of the basketball stadium for weeks prior to a game for coveted seats.

Duke is consistently ranked among the top universities in the United States and globally and is particularly known for its programs in business, law, medicine, engineering, public policy, and the sciences. As a leading research institution, the university attracts significant funding and produces groundbreaking research across various fields. The Duke University Medical Center is particularly noted for its contributions to medical research and healthcare innovation.

Many leaders in business, entertainment, and politics call Duke their alma mater. Famous Duke University graduates include President Richard Nixon, Apple CEO Tim Cook, CBS Sports President Sean McManus, Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist William Styron, philanthropist Melinda Gates, and television personality Charlie Rose.

How diverse is Duke?

Duke is diverse in multiple aspects, including racial, ethnic, socioeconomic, and geographic diversity. In the Class of 2027, 55% of students identified as female, 45% as male. Additionally, 13% of students identified as Hispanic/Latinx, 35% as Asian, 13% as Black or African American, 1.2% as Native American, and 53% white. Fourteen percent of students were international, while 86% were domestic. Students also came from diverse educational backgrounds, with 58% from public school, 25% from independent schools, and 13% from schools outside of the U.S.

How do I apply to Duke?

You can apply to Duke through both the Common Application and the Coalition Application either in the Early Decision round (deadline: November 1) or in the Regular Decision round (deadline: January 2). Duke also accepts Questbridge applications. The following materials are required for application to Duke:

Official high school transcript, submitted by your school counselor or another school official

SAT or ACT scores or superscore (Optional for the 2024-25 application cycle)

An English proficiency test is recommended for non-native English speakers

One mandatory supplemental short-answer of 250 words in addition to your Common or Coalition App Essay

Two optional supplemental short-answers

Three letters of recommendation—one from your counselor and two from teachers who taught you in a major academic course (English, Mathematics, Social Studies, Science, or Foreign Language). If you are applying to the Pratt School of Engineering, at least one recommendation should be from a math or science teacher.

An $85 application fee

Additionally, you can submit the following optional materials:

Additional recommendation letter from an employer or mentor

Interview with an alumni

Artistic Supplement submitted through the SlideRoom Portal

Does Duke have a good athletic department?

Duke athletes, the Blue Devils, compete on 27 varsity sports teams in the NCAA Division I. The Duke Blue Devils men’s basketball team is one of the most successful and well-known programs in NCAA history, with 5 national championships. The university’s commitment to athletics extends to a wide range of varsity and intramural sports, fostering a vibrant campus spirit. If you’re not competing in Division I sports, you can still play your sport on a club or intramural team.

What are Duke’s core curriculum and programs?

Duke University’s core curriculum, known as the “Trinity College of Arts & Sciences Curriculum,” is designed to provide students with a broad education while allowing for in-depth study in their chosen major. ​​Students must take courses across five broad Areas of Knowledge to ensure exposure to diverse fields of study: Arts, Literature, and Performance; Civilization; Natural Science; Social Science; and Quantitative Studies. Students are also required to engage in different “Modes of Inquiry,” which are cross-cutting perspectives that shape how they approach learning: Cross-Cultural Inquiry; Science, Technology, and Society; Ethical Inquiry; Writing; and Foreign Language.

Duke’s Trinity College of Arts and Sciences offers Bachelor of Science and Bachelor of Art degrees in 48 majors, 50 minors, and 23 certificates. It also boasts the option to create an interdepartmental major by taking courses from two majors or an alternative major to design a student’s own curriculum through Program II. At many colleges with a required core, these classes provide the freshman class with the opportunity for shared experiences; it’s possible you’ll meet some of your closest college friends in your freshman year writing course or your freshman year seminar.

Duke’s Pratt School of Engineering offers degrees in biomedical, civil, environmental, electrical and computer, and mechanical engineering majors, as well as minors in machine learning and artificial intelligence, electrical & computer and energy engineering. Pratt has core requirements of its own, which differ from those of Trinity.

Can I afford Duke?

The estimated total cost of attendance at Duke ranges from $93,330-$94,066, including room and board, fees, and average personal expenses. Students at Duke pay on a sliding scale based on their financial circumstances, and Duke is committed to meeting 100% of financial need for every student. More than half of students at Duke receive financial aid, and 12% of the student body is made up of first-generation college students. If you want to get a better idea of what your financial aid package would look like, you can use Duke’s net price calculator.
